title: Humpback Whale Supergroups
content: Humpback whales, some of nature's largest aquatic animals, have been the focus of scientific research for decades, but in the past several years, researchers have begun to witness strange, unforeseen behavior that they have yet to explain. Starting in 2011, researchers reported sighting the whales forming so-called supergroups. The groups, consisting of anywhere from twenty to two hundred of the animals, were largely sighted off the southwest coast of Africa, and experts say that no previous reports have mentioned such large gatherings. Additionally, scientists are at a loss to explain the location of the sightings, as humpback whales primarily feed near the southern region of Antarctica. One promising theory suggests that the behavior is a result of the whales experiencing a population boom since the 1960s, when whaling was banned by many nations, and that this type of supergrouping might have actually been the norm for humpbacks when they existed in greater numbers. For now, however, scientists continue to study the animals in hopes of unraveling their mysteries.

title: The SV Resolven
content: On August 29, 1884, the HMS Mallard came upon an eerily abandoned merchant vessel, the Welsh SV Resolven, in the Labrador Sea between Baccalieu Island and Catalina. The vessel's lifeboat was missing, and the last log book recording was written six hours before. There was little damage to the ship, and it was operating sufficiently. Eventually, the abandoned ship was towed to a port and put out to sea gain. Some locals questioned if the crew and passengers were unused to the cold waters and had panicked after a small collision with a nearby iceberg. (The collision did not affect the ship's integrity or ability to float.) Perhaps they abandoned the ship out of fear and lost control of their lifeboat. However, there has never been any trace of the eleven people who were traveling aboard the vessel. More mysteriously, the skipper, John James, was said to have had his gold coin collection on board with him during the journey, and collection was not found on the abandoned ship, leaving many questioning if those valuables could have had something to do with the vessel's disappearance.

title: The Tully Monster
content: First unearthed in the 150s by a man named Francis Tully, the fossilized remains of a creature that came to be named Tullimonstrum, or the Tully monster, have confounded researchers ever since their discovery in the Mazon Creek fossil beds in Illinois. At almost three hundred million years old, the Tully monster is the only such fossil ever found and seems to have belonged to one of history's most bizarre creatures. Described at first as slugh-like, the Tully monster is thought to have had a long, thin appendage tipped in claws where a mout would normally be, with protruding eye stalks. So strange is the fossil that scientists still hotly debate whether the creature was a vertebrate or invertebrate and how to classify it. Even after employing particle accelerator technology to examine the Tully monster's remains, the verdict is still out about the beast, but scientists can almost entirely agree that the creature stands as one of history's most enduring evolutionary mysteries.

title: J. C. Brown and the Underground City
content: In 1904, British explorer J. C. Brown claimed to have found an entire underground city beneath Mount Shasta, a volcano at the southern top of the Cascade Range near Siskiyou County, California. Brown had been searching for gold deposits on behalf of the Lord Cowdray Mining Company, but during his search, he found a deep cave opening to an underground city loaded with artifacts. In the 1930s, around thirty years after his discovery, he shared the story of what he found on this expedicion with a close colleague. Brown and his colleague started to form a group to travel to the location with supplies, but on their departure date, Brown did not meet the group to take them to the treasure. In fact, he was never seen again, and the group was unable to locate the valuable in the cave he claimed to have found.

title: The Tingling Science of ASMR
content: Autonomous sensory meridian response, or ASMR, has become something of a minor sentation since the early 2000s when YouTubers and other content creators began recording themselves making specific sorts of sounds. Though the practice has since grown, with millions of viewers tuning in to experience the tingling sensation provoked by such sounds, very little scientific research has been conducted on how ASMR works. Recently, researchers from the University of Winnipeg implemented functional MRI technology to record the brain activity of people as they were exposed to ASMR. The study attempted to explain why some people react strongly to the sounds, experiencing a type of tingling sensation in their brain and nerves, while others show no reaction whatsoever. While ambitious, the research failed to unravel the mystery of ASMR, instead providing even more questions as to how it works. While future studies are planned to explore the subject, for now most are content to simply sit back, relax, and enjoy the mystery.

title: Richard Nixon's Missing Recording
content: In the early 1970s, the United States erupted in a storm of political controvery when details of the Watergate scandal were exposed to the public. President Richard Nixon had been one of the most thorough presidents in recording his Oval Office conversations for reference and historical significance, so when investigators discovered that one recording made on June 20, 1972, had a mysterious eighteen-and-a-half-minute gap, suspicions immediately intensified. The tape in question happened to be the one featuring Nixon's discussion of the break-in at the Democratic National Committee headquesters. Nixon's personal secretary, Rose Mary Woods, admitted to being responsible for five minutes of the deletion, but her error did not account for an additional thirteen minutes of missing audio. It was never determined how the audio was deleted, what was recorded, or who altered the recording. Today, the National Archives stores the material in a climate-controlled vault in hopes of new technology someday being able to recover the lost material and information.

title: The Marree Man
content: On June 26, 1998, a pilot flying over Finnis Springs in the township of Marree in South Australia discovered a massive geoglyph below, depicting a native man hunting with some type of stick. The figure is massive in size, measuring 1.7 miles tall, spanning an area of over six hundred acres. Experts believe the geoglyph was created in modern times, claiming local artists or even military members serving in the area could have been its originators. They say the orchestrators most likely used some type of GPS technology to create the massive artwork, and considering how new the technology was at the time, they say the accomplishment is remarkable. Interestingly, anonymous faxes were sent to local businesses alerting people of the artwork's location just before the pilot spotted it from the air. Although the faxes observe American spelling and some American materials were found near the location, officials believe the artist or artists were intentionally misleading people to withhold their identities. Australian officials are still unsure who created the piece.

title: The Lost Library of Ivan the Terrible
content: The library of Ivan the Terrible - Ivan IV Vasilyevich, the first czar of Russia from 1547 to 1584 - is rumored to have been started by Ivan III, his grandfather, and it is presumed to have held some of the most ancient and secretive texts ever produced. The collection included items written in Egyptian, Greek, Hebrew, and Latin, as well as Chinese texts dating to the second century. Old records of its contents claimed it had a full version of Cicero's De re publica as well as over 140 volumes of Titus Livius's History of Rome, of which only thirty-five exist today. Ivan the Terrible was rumored to have stored these texts under the Kremlin, but after his death in 1584, the library is said to have disappeared. Since then, countless attempts have been made to locate it, including official searches of the Kremlin and other estates the czars frequented, but with no luck.

title: The Loch Ness Monster
content: The legend of the Loch Ness Monster started fifteen hundred years ago when Saint Columba, an Irish missionary, stated that he had encountered a beat in Loch Ness in the highlands of Scotland. Since then, many sightings of the monster have surfaced, and they now average roughly ten reports every year. The creature, affectionately named "Nessie", is decribed as looking like a plesiosaur, a long-necked marine reptiles that died out with the dinosaurs. In 2018, the first minister of Scotland, Nicola Sturgeon, said that she believes in Nessie, and Scotland is doing research to try to find the truth. Scottish officials have even drawn up plans to protect the beast, partially done in jest. Past searches for the Loch Ness Monster have been fruitless despite numerous reported sightings, but Scottish Natural Heritage, the agency in charge of the most recent search, believes that new technology will help it finally find answers.

title: The Max Headroom TV Hijacking
content: On November 22, 1987, two television stations in Chicago had broadcasts hijacked by an unknown person impersonating the character Max Headroom, an artificial intelligence character that debuted in the early 1980s in the television movie Max Headroom: 20 Minutes in the Future. Both Chicago stations WGN-TV and WTTW were interrupted separately within a span of three hours. The intruder made references to the television series Clutch Cargo of the 1960s and to news anchors and even exposed himself while a second intruder smacked him in the butt with a flyswatter. The incident made national headlines. The Federal Communications Commission investigated the hijacking, but no one was ever charged with the pirating.

title: Planet X
content: Ever Since August 2006, when Pluto was downgraded to a dwarf planet by the International Astronomical Union, our solar system as only official claimed eight planets. Recent research, however, hints at the existence of a mysterious ninth planet, known as Planet X, somewhere far past even Pluto, in the dark recesses of space beyond the research of most of our most advanced sensors and technology. While the combined efforts of sixty thousands science-minded volunteers, poring over troves of data and information, could not produce hard evidence of such a planet, experts say that they do have indirect evidence of its existence. Specifically, they say that it appears as if the orbits of several objects in our solar system, located in the distant Kuiper Belt, are being affected by a massive, unknown body theorized to be at least as large as Neptune. While current technology cannot yet confirm the presence of such a shadowy planet, which is said to be one thousand times dimmer than Pluto, experts are hopeful that coming advancments in detection equipment and telescopes, paired with machine deep learning, will help reveal the identity of the lurking ninth planet.

title: The Death of Edgar Allan Poe
content: Author Edgar Allan Poe was known for his poem "The Raven" and other short stories and poetry, mostly depicting dark and mysterious themes. Unfortunately, his fiction work was not the only aspect of his life affected by mysterious circumstances. The writer died at age forty on October 7, 1849, in Baltimore, Maryland, and only a few strange details were gathered regarding his passing. Four days before his death, he was found stumbling around Baltimore in a delirious state and wearing someone else's clothing. Random passersby reported his condition, and he was taken to Washington Medical College, where he eventually died. Records show he repeatedly yelled the name "Reynolds" just before his death. There are no medical records or death certificates regarding Poe's passing, and no definitive cause of death was determined, making the famed writer's death as strange and dark as his own stories.

title: Mona Lisa's Twin
descriptor: Easter Monday (AUS, CAN, NZ, UK except SCT)
content: Perhaps the most famed Renaissance painter to have ever held a brush, Leonardo da Vinci produced surprisingly few paintings, with many experts placing the number of pieces definitively painted by him at just fifteen over the entirety of his fifty-year career. Any discovery of previously unknown da Vinci paintings, then, is both intensely scrutinized and wildly important. Previously known as the Isleworth Mona Lisa but christened the "Earlier Mona Lisa"by its current owners, one portrait is seemingly an earlier iteration of the painter's most famed work, the Mona Lisa, which many experts claim he painted in dribs and drabs over the course of a decade. Visibly similar to its later, more famous counterpart, the Isleworth Mona Lisa depicts its model at a younger age. It is so similar to the Mona Lisa that numerous reputable art organizations have cautiously confirmed the painting's authenticity as a da Vinci original. Nonetheless, skeptics still abound, with many considering the Isleworth Mona Lisa to be nothing more than a convincing forgery.

title: The Lost Crew of the Zebrina
content: On September 17, 1917, the Zebrina, a schooner being used to transport coal between Cornwall in the United Kingdom and France, was found beached in Cherbourg, France, without any trace of her five crew members. Rescuers found the ship was without any damage. Some questioned whether the crew could have been accidentally washed overboard in big swells, but that theory was quickly ruled out considering the pristine state of the deck and its contents. Others questioned whether the boat was actually an undercover Q-boat, a bout used to intentionally engage with German U-boats in hopes of wrecking them. However, the log book was aboard, and the Germans almost always confiscated or destroyed them after taking over enemy ships. Rescuers searched for signs of drowning around the ship, but nothing was ever found. A memorial was erected in the crew member's honor in London.

title: 'Oumuamua, the Cosmic Visitor
content: Throughout the years, many have claimed to have been visited by travelers from another planet, and while the reliability of such claims has varied wildly, very few have been made by someone as well respected in the field of astrophysics and the study of our universe as Avi Loeb. A world-renowned scientist and leading member of the Dpartment of Astrophysics at Harvard University, Loeb has pioneered research into potentially world-changing sciences such as gamma-ray bursts and black hole physics. He also firmly believes that we have been visited by aliens - and recently. Loeb claims that a mysterious interllar object named 'Oumuamua, meaning "scout" in the Hawaiian language, which entered our solar system in 2017, was actually the product of aliens doing a survey of our space. Supporting his claims by citing 'Oumuamua bizarre, cigar-like structure and unprecedented reflective qualities, Loeb also says that the object's movement and trajectory can only be explained by deliberate propulsion. Despite his outstanding pedigree in the field, Dr. Loeb's claims were met with harsh skepticism, though even his skeptics could only produce thin theories for the object's appearance and behavior.

title: The Cecil Hotel
content: When it comes to real estate with a grisly past, few can compare to the Cecil Hotel in Los Angeles. First constructued in 1927, the Cecil Hotel has been the home of an extraordinary number of unexplained and gruesome events. In the 1950s and 1960s, the premises showed an influx of people visiting the hotel for the sole purpose of committing suicide. Later, Richard Ramirez, a seriel killer also known as "the Night Stalker," allegedly stayed in the hotel from 1984 to 1985. Jack Unterweger, an Austrian serial killer, also stayed at the hotel in 1991 and killed three prostitutes during his stay, murdering them after bringing them to his room. In February 2013, the body of Elisa Lam, a Canadian tourist, was found at the bottom of the water tank located on the roof. And perhaps more questionable, in 2015, Koston Alderete, who visited the hotel, took a picture that he believes shows a ghost in one of the fourth-floor windows. Though supernatural forces may not be at work here, the bizarre draw of the Cecil Hotel for those seeking death and violence is storied and very real.

title: The L-8 Blimp Mystery
content: On August 16th, 1942, the L-8 Navy blimp was seen flying at a dangerously low elevation near Fort Funston in San Francisco, California. The blimp had been sent on a routing mission to fly toward the Farallon Islands, about thirty miles from San Francisco, circle the area, and return to Treasure Island, the departure location. The blimp touched down on a beach briefly before rising up slowly again and eventually crashing into a hill and rolling down. It finally touched down in front of a residence on Bellevue Avenue in Daly City, California. When the craft landed, no crew or passengers were aboard. The recorded crew were two very experienced airmen, and all lifeboats and parachutes were still on board the aircraft, most likely ruling out any attempts at escaping above the sea. Also, the radio on board was still functioning, and no distress calls were recorded before the blimp's appearance. Although they were never found and no explanation surfaced, the two men listed aboard the craft were legally declared dead one year after the event.

title: The Marching Octopuses
content: In October 2017, a recreational dolphin-watching group in Wales discovered something very bizarre: twenty to thirty octopuses crawling on land, some as far as thirty feet inland. To help the animals, the group brought them back to the water. When the watchers returned the next morning, they found that more octopuses had climbed back onto the beach and subsequently died. Strangely, the cephalopods showed no signs that they had been attacked or injured. Scientists debate the cause of this peculia behavior, but a leading theory is that overpopulation forced these octopuses to come ashore, while others believe that they could just be coming to shore as a form of deliberate suicide. Some marine biologists place the blame on environmental changes in the area. Despite a wealth of theories, however, no concrete explanation has ever been agreed upon for the animals' behavior.

title: The Marching Octopuses
content: In October 2017, a recreational dolphin-watching group in Wales discovered something very bizarre: twenty to thirty octopuses crawling on land, some as far as thirty feet inland. To help the animals, the group brought them back to the water. When the watchers returned the next morning, they found that more octopuses had climbed back onto the beach and subsequently died. Strangely, the cephalopods showed no signs that they had been attacked or injured. Scientists debate the cause of this peculia behavior, but a leading theory is that overpopulation forced these octopuses to come ashore, while others believe that they could just be coming to shore as a form of deliberate suicide. Some marine biologists place the blame on environmental changes in the area. Despite a wealth of theories, however, no concrete explanation has ever been agreed upon for the animals' behavior.

title: The Phantom Barber of Pascagoula
content: For a single week during 1942 in the small town of Pascagoula, Mississippi, citizens were terrorized by what came to be known as the "Phantom Barber." Starting on June 5 of that year, the barber forcibly entered four different homes and cut the hair of his sleeping victims. Only once was the barber spotted, by parents of two young victims who described him as "shorta short, sorta fat" but otherwise nondescript. In three of the four hair-cutting cases, no one was injured. Only on Friday of that week, when he entered the home of Mr. and Mrs. Heidelberg, did he attack his victims. The barber used an iron bar to knock Mr. Heidelberg unconscious and knocked out some of Mrs. Heidelberg's teeth before proceeding to cut their hair. Following this final attack, the Phantom Barber was never seen again, and police were never able to provide any explanation or potential motive for the crimes.

title: The Disappearance of Judge Joseph Force Crater
content: On August 6, 1930, New York Supreme Court judge Joseph Force Crater met a friend for dinner at a New York steakhouse. He was last seen walking down the street away from the restaurant, and no one heard from him again. The story of Judge Crater's disappearance cased an avalanche of media coverage and public interest. It took authorities nine years of no solid evidence or closure to officially declare him dead in 1939. Crater was known for being involved with corrupt politicians and nightlife, and the week of his famous disappearance, he had received mysterious calls and cashed some large checks. There were also rumors his judicial appointment was tainted with bribery, which some speculated could have led to his disappearance and probably death. In 2005, authorities were tipped off that his body was possibly buried underneath the boardwalk on Coney Island, but that site had been excavated in the 1950s, so the possible breakthrough in the case could never be looked into.
